review_text: Everything looked great...that is until the assembly began. First, note that I didn’t not use the cheap wrench that supplied. I consider myself a very hand person and I used the correct socket size. I placed the bolt through the bar and connected to the plastic bar the you place on the door. This is where it all goes downhill. Even though the bolts had a square notch that seats into the plastic bar, it is weak and will not hold the bolt when you begin to tighten it. So basically....it just keeps spinning and eventually rounds the plastic hole. Needles to say, I was pretty disappointed and I have ordered a different brand that will hopefully be more robust than this bar. Half a star for trying, but this is going back.

product_name: iron gym total upper body workout bar
review_header: Very sturdy and easy to put together
review_text: Very sturdy and easy to put together. Because of the size and door fitting, it's hard to do wide pull ups but regular pull ups and lower leg raises makes it easy to use at home or wherever.

product_name: iron gym total upper body workout bar
review_header: Amazing product -- assuming it fits your door. I just wish it was adjustable.
review_text: I have owned several of these and they're great. You just have to make sure it fits your door frame and surround area. Many bedroom and bathroom doorways are really too small for this, and the unit is not adjustable. I've found that doors along the size of exterior entryways are more suitable. Perhaps a side garage door, etc. That being said, if it fits your door, or is close enough (there's a bit of wiggle room using the outer hand grips as pads,) it's a very solid and usable unit. You will get many, many years of use, even if you use it all day long.

product_name: iron gym total upper body workout bar
review_text: I had an Iron Gym 10 years ago in a different home, used it all the time and loved it. I rate this one that I just purchased only one star because it doesn't fit the doors in my new home and the description doesn't address door thickness. The description states it "is designed to fit residential doorways 24 to 32 inches wide, with doorway trim or molding up to 3.5 inches wide." My door is 32 inches wide and my molding is 3.5 inches wide. It should also specify that it will not safely fit doorways greater than a certain thickness. Every doorway in my house, including the molding thickness, is 8 inches thick. At this thickness and with my molding width, the plastic bar barely squeezes onto the molding and hangs halfway off. To be fair if I put weight on the Iron Gym, the pressure pushes the bar further onto the frame however I just don't feel safe using it in this situation.

product_name: iron gym total upper body workout bar
review_header: Great for DIY autistic swings holders and other exercise toys for kids that you can take down with little hassle.
review_text: This was just the thing we needed! I didn't use it at all for pull ups or work outs whatsoever. I needed something to put in my door way so that I could use an autistic swing for my kids, as well as other things for my ADHD child to climb up. So I got this and since the bars are a little to wide for swings to be attached to it. So I used Ankle Straps for Cable Machines that had 2 metal hoops on it to make the swing be able to hook to the pull up bar. We also use a child's climb rope which nicely hangs their as well and has never budged from the area where it rests on. It was easy to put together, and since the weight limit is 300 I feel 100% safe that my kids and their toys that are on there will not come down. It is very sturdy and I am not going to lie at first I put all my weight on while it was on the doorway there just to make sure the molding wasn't going to come down (just because I am paranoid about things like that when evolving kids) and it has never budged once, I weigh about 200 pounds. So over all great for our needs!

product_name: iron gym total upper body workout bar
review_header: Good pull-up bar, but certain precautions necessary
review_text: I purchased this in August of 2015 and it has served its purpose well. Assembly was easy. If I remember correctly, it took me less than 30 minutes. I don’t use it for anything else other than pull ups and chin-ups, but I’m sure it’ll be good for pushups and sit-ups. I question how effective dips would be on this since it seems a bit too low to do a full movement dip. It has handled my weight (145 lbs) well and has not started to bend or sag. I do have a couple of complaints, the padding on the bar where it meets the door frame should be thicker. Mine degraded without me noticing and the actual solid bar started to push against my doorframe. Now my doorframe is damaged. I recommend putting a sock between the doorframe and the bar to provide more padding for protection. My other complaint is that the flat piece that goes against the wall above the doorframe could discolor your wall. It did mine. I recommend putting something in between the wall and the flat plastic part to prevent against this. Other than that, this is a well built product that performs as advertised.

product_name: iron gym total upper body workout bar
review_text: When I first bought this bar, I set it up and used it maybe one time. After trying it out I couldn’t even do one pullup, but I kept at for about 1 week, and by the end of that week, I could easily do 5. I made a game plan; every week I would push my max and add five more pull-ups a few minutes after. Since using this routine I have noticed serious changes. I increased muscle mass, lost weight, and was even able to tone some pre-existing muscles. Since I’ve bought this product I have lost a majority of my gynecomastia, gained 2-3 inches on my biceps, toned all my upper body muscles, and even set a path for a six pack! After using this bar I can confidently say that I have increased my max amount of pull-ups from 0 to 20 comfortably. I would absolutely reccomend this to anyone who wants to get ripped without leaving home.

product_name: iron gym total upper body workout bar
review_header: Works well in an NYC apartment
review_text: I've been using this workout bar in my apartment for the past six months with great success. For one thing, it's ever present so I have no excuse for not using it. And it is easy to attach to the door frame with no apparent damage. For another, it works -- I went from one pull up to six pull ups after three months, and can now do eight. Pretty good for an 80 year old codger. Robert C. Ross December 2017

review_header: This bar is fantastic. I put it in my basement and hold ...
review_text: This bar is fantastic. I put it in my basement and hold regular contests with.my friends as to who can do the most pull-ups. Typically, we're in our boxers, but nothing romantic goes on. This club, founded mostly through Craigslist, is all about dat fitness lyfe #newbeginnings. When I was in prison, I didn't get the opportunity to work out on such a bar. But thanks to the Iron Gym Total Upper Body Workout, I am five pounds heavier, and can lift large boxes are my job at Staples. Thanks, Amazon! I greatly appreciate it. Sincerely, Diego

product_name: iron gym total upper body workout bar
review_header: Look for one with center bolts!
review_text: This seems to be a decent product except for a major flaw that I anticipate will drastically shorten it's life. The long bar that crosses the doorway is two separate pieces that fit together in the center. They don't fit tightly. I've tried altering the bolts of the cross pieces to get a better fit without success. The metal ends only overlap by about an inch and there is bend as you put weight on the bar. Once I realized this was an issue, I looked more carefully and saw that other bars have bolts to hold the middle pieces together. I think that would make the whole device safer and that you should definitely look for a bar with these center bolts. Maybe I can find a metal bar to fit inside the center pieces for added stability. Or drill my own bolt holes.

How is that supposed to hold me? Every time I tightened it it would come apart. I got 2/3 of the way done but when I got to the point where you attach the long bar to the U shaped bar, the screw holes were the wrong shape! The screws did not fit at all! I’m super disappointed but have to return this and purchase a different brand preferably in a store.

review_text: not happy with it at all. the plastic bar was bent and instead of having 4 bolts in total, i only got 3. plus the bolts don’t even tighten properly. it’s all loose and everything and not safe to use. some of the bolts weren’t even long enough to screw in either. if everything was all nice and tighty then this would be a good product. Also, it’d be nice to not have a bent plastic bar and to have all the bolts. none of this stuff was right at all.

product_name: iron gym total upper body workout bar
review_text: Terrible terrible materials for putting the product together. The product itself may be FANTASTIC, but if you can't even properly complete the assembly process, then it's useless. What should be the easiest assembly has wrong parts for doing so. As a result of NOT being able to properly tighten the bolts provide. The wall protecting plastic bar is made of poor material in which the bolts easily stripped the plastic when trying to even loosely tighten it. On top of that, there's no way of reversing the bolt tightening process (I was going to switch out the bolts for personal ones that contain a screwdriver access head so that you can hold the bolt in place on one end while tightening on the other...the ones provided don't allow for that) , but as a result of not having that, I can't switch out the bolt. This leaves me with a loose dangling arm, which basically means that I can't use the product. Not sure of anyone had this same experience, but I would suggest that Iron Gym switch out some of its assembly parts for more logical and sturdy materials. Unfortunate bc I was looking forward to using this, and now I can't even return this product for a refund.

product_name: iron gym total upper body workout bar
review_text: I goto the local gym maybe 3 times a week due to my schedule and just having a reasonable goal to accomplish. Therefore, I sometimes have an itching to get in a workout but not spend 3-4 hours in the gym. The pull bar does the trick. After I brush my teeth or if I'm waiting for water to boil when cooking, I throw up this bar on the door and crank out maybe 15 to feel the burn. I could use it more so for a full workout because of the push up handles, but I think I like it the most is because I can really get the body working in a short set of pull ups. It's also portable and easy to store. Some folks leave their bar up at all times, but I have my girlfriend in the house and I'm sure she wouldn't appreciate the vibe of a pull up bar in front of the bedroom. That's why it's great that I can easy take it off and store it in the closest without taking too much space. Overall not a bad tool for a decent price

product_name: everydrop by whirlpool refrigerator water filter 1 (pack of 1)
review_header: Great replacement filter for Whirlpool fridge
review_text: I was skeptical about buying the water filter after all the negative reviews, but it surprised me. My fridge was new and this is the first time I had to change the filter. Whatever filter was already IN the fridge had a terrible plastic taste so I was concerned that it would stay around with the new filter. To my big surprise it was much better. I only drink spring water and have drank from the filter and liked it- it had no after taste or plastic taste anymore. I did have some air bubbles following the filter change but it does go away after a little while. I made sure to run the water before the first use (as directed) although I didn't measure the water so was it exactly however many gallons??? No idea! I am very happy with my purchase and will only order this filter for my Whirpool fridge.

product_name: everydrop by whirlpool refrigerator water filter 1 (pack of 1)
review_header: I think I got a bad one.
review_text: I think I got a bad one because I've used this filter before in our same fridge and it was great. This time though, the water tastes funny, like something biological is not getting filtered out..there's a slight rotten taste. The new funky taste appeared when we replaced this same EveryDrop model filter with the new one. The old EveryDrop one still had 2% of use on it according to our fridge, but we replaced it with this new one and the water immediately tasted weird. I went on Amazon to see if I could get a free replacement but I'd have to return the old one. That is not easy to do. It's wet, it's been used and is still being used until we can replace it. So, I've just been waiting for enough time to pass that buying another fridge filter makes financial sense. Not sure I'll buy this one though.

product_name: everydrop by whirlpool refrigerator water filter 1 (pack of 1)
review_header: This is a tiny ICE & WATER filter for your freezer compartment-- NOT a normal fullsize water filter for your frig (below).
review_text: So, just in case others are not paying attention (like me) -- this is an ICE & WATER filter (NOT the big one for the bottom of your side-by-side frig). This is tiny, tiny, tiny. It's for up in your ice maker compartment. I don't have one there -- I have the big one at the bottom for the whole frig. The filter selector said that this model would fit my Whirlpool Side-by-Side -- it doesn't.

product_name: everydrop by whirlpool refrigerator water filter 1 (pack of 1)
review_header: The only one that worked for me
review_text: I went through about six different water filters from various brands trying to find one that would work for my four year old Kenmore refrigerator on my last refill. Up until that point I had been successful using 3rd party filters. This time there was a change in the design for the filters by all manufacturers. Each one would fit fine but I could not get any pressure at all, just a hammering sound. This official Whirlpool filter worked right away, producing better water flow than I have gotten with any of the other filter manufacturers. I didn't notice any difference in the taste of the water. The filter was troublesome after the first night and I had to adjust it a few more times before it was just right to keep the water flowing. No problems in the month since. I knocked one point off since it is a little pricey.

product_name: everydrop by whirlpool refrigerator water filter 1 (pack of 1)
review_header: This product was useful but I prefer a lower price for this product
review_text: This product was hard for me to find and choose. Finding Whirlpool/Amanda water filters for my fridge unit took a lot of time and effort until I finally came to this product. Although I feel that the price for this product is too high, it was one of the only options we'd got to find a filter that would replace our outdated water filter in our fridge. I was hoping to find a water filter branded by either Whirlpool/Amanda or at least the same brand as the filter they've already installed in my fridge. This product was bought because our old filter reached its 6-month limit and after a few months of use, the water change taste. We had no choice but to but a new one and luckily we found this filter which was compatible. After installing, you have to throw out some of the water and ice from the fridge as instructed in the manual. To install, there is this square compartment on the bottom of the fridge (outside). Pull it and the filter pops right out. Replace and push tight to close the compartment. This product was useful but I prefer a lower price for this product.

My only complaint is that when it is first installed, the instructions say you have to flush the filter for 4 gallons. All of the other ones would cause the water dispenser on my Whirlpool fridge to hammer/knock and only spit out an intermittent stream of water. This filter worked great from the get go with no issues in the last month or so that I've had it. My wife said she noticed a taste, but I haven't noticed a difference beyond "different than tap water". I've been happy with it, just wish they weren't so expensive.

With my Gunnar's as a point of reference, these glasses were a total failure. They certainly aren't the most comfortable. One side of the ear pieces felt like it was going to snap when adjusting it. They fit VERY snugly. I could live with the fit if the picture they provide wasn't somewhat distorted and drastically oranged. With my Gunnar's, there is a tint but you can still see and differentiate other colors. With these Uvex, There are no other colors. Just orange. I wouldn't recommend them for computer glare and blue light reduction.

review_header: Use Before Bedtime - Helps With Sleeping
review_text: I go to bed early and needed help sleeping with this odd sleep schedule - this product helps. I try to put these on before I go to bed or when I go to bed, either way I use them before I plan to crash. The only odd part is the lack of the color blue, I am a gamer so the missing color makes gaming more "interesting". When watching TV the missing color isn't too bad, just a bit odd. I just remind myself this is helping me sleep in a few minutes and to suck it up. Bottom line: I believe this works so I recommend for those having difficulty sleeping, just remember to start early. Read the other reviews for this product as I did to educate yourself on how this works too, it is helpful to know how and why it works.

product_name: uvex skyper blue light blocking computer glasses with sct-orange lens (s1933x)
review_header: You really do need blue light protection. This is an inexpensive way to get it.
review_text: I got these glasses for my grandchildren. They spend a lot of time on the computer and I'm afraid of the cumulative damage of computer use, TV watching, tablet use, and whatever other blue-light producing products they engage in. If I can cut down on some of the blue-light damage, this is a cost effective and practical way to do it. It fits my 9-year old grandson perfectly but is a bit loose on the 5-year old (who still uses it because it looks cool).They have no graduation. For me, I've been using another blue-light set of glasses that has the +1.50 graduation I need for my vision on computer screens. My ophthalmologist told me it was a great idea and he highly recommended the protection. Basically, you figure the graduation you may need by ordering a level that is half your reading glasses strength. So, since my reading glasses are +3.00.I halved it and got the +1.50 which works perfectly. Does it affect colors? Yes, especially the first few minutes. After that, you forget they're there. If you use your computer for processing photos or designing graphics etc, you might need to, occasionally, lift the glasses up to make sure you're not over-yellowing. But for video watching, computer games, and office documents (Word, Excel, etc) it really doesn't interfere.

review_header: Very yellow. Blocks blue as described. Better sleep...we will see.
review_text: These were recommended to me so I thought I'd give them a shot. They actually fit my small face pretty well. I'm asian and have a flatter nose. I was expecting it to be way too large but, they are okay. They do slide down off my face a bit but, I guess I could place a shim on the bottom of the lenses where it touches my face to help keep them up...or use some sort of tie to fasten it to my head. I wear this 2 hours before I go to sleep. It's been only a week so, I don't notice a measurable difference. I'm still getting used to watching a movie without any blues and brushing my teeth with these googles on. After two hours, I'm glad to be able to take them off mostly because they are large and I'm just not used to them. I use a computer for hours but I would not use these to play video games or on the computer. Try blue blocking glasses that aren't as yellow. You'll still get some benefit and not blow out all the blues. I'm glad I tried this product. It was a good price and $9 is not a big investment to see if using them can help me sleep better and more sound.

product_name: uvex skyper blue light blocking computer glasses with sct-orange lens (s1933x)
review_text: As far as blue blocking, these are the best glasses by far of the many I've tried in the low to moderate price range. In an online, two image comparison graphic for testing the effectiveness of blue blocking lenses, both images appear identical when I'm wearing the glasses. They are very comfortable on my small, woman's head, have adjustable temples and fit very close to my face all the way around. The nose bridge on these glasses is molded into the lens and is not quite as comfortable as Smith & Wesson Magnum 3G glasses which have a silicone (?) nose piece but it does interfere less with vision. The lenses wrap around giving good side protection from blue light. These are very nice, inexpensive blue blockers. I wish Uvex made an over-prescription-glasses model with the SCT-orange lens, that would be perfect.

product_name: uvex skyper blue light blocking computer glasses with sct-orange lens (s1933x)
review_text: Couldn't be happier! I performed two online blue light tests on these glasses. They passed BOTH!! The first picture is what the screen looks like without glasses. The second picture is of these Uvex glasses that passed the test and the third picture is of GammaRay glasses that DIDN'T pass. I bought these used off amazon and they were sent new looking!!! Burns my eyes to look at the screen after I take these glasses off! Never knew what I was missing. For the price they are well worth it!!!

product_name: uvex skyper blue light blocking computer glasses with sct-orange lens (s1933x)
review_text: I'm actually really surprised with these. I bought them for wearing at night so my sleep schedule doesn't get messed up, and also for wearing while I'm reading textbooks on my computer. I was very hesitant to buy these because I thought they would be too dark. They're not at all like sunglasses, however. I can wear them with minimal lighting inside the house at night and not stumble over anything. It seems as though they really do block only the blue light, leaving all the other light pretty much alone so you can still see. Yes, everything will have an orange tint, but I was able to quickly adjust to it. I feel like it actually improves contrast in some cases. Reading black text on a yellow-ish background from a computer screen is actually easier because my eyes don't strain from the uncomfortable blue light. Highly recommend.

If you wear them without glasses, they fit so snugly to the face that they fog up. Then they must be removed and cleaned while you keep your eyes shut so that you do not get a dose of melatonin-blocking blue light.

product_name: uvex skyper blue light blocking computer glasses with sct-orange lens (s1933x)
review_header: they are a great investment. I started to wear these about a ...
review_text: Cost - at only $10, they are a great investment. I started to wear these about a month ago after researching some sleep studies. I found one to be implemented by a college football team to help their players improve their sleep. Repeating their process, I put these glasses on about 1 hour before going to bed. I continue to watch TV and interact with the family in the house. One hour later, I turn off everything, remove the glass and fall asleep within 3-5 minutes. Previously, I would be awake another 30-45 minutes before falling asleep. After 2 weeks, I found myself staying asleep for longer periods of time. Previously, I was waking up 2-3x a night. Just recently, I started to remove caffeine and sugar after 6pm. This helped even more. Placebo? Not sure, but I know my eyes are no longer burning during the day, I am falling asleep faster (within 3-5 minutes) and out of the past 5 days, I may wake up once in the middle of two different nights and not wake up until the morning for the other 3 nights. I have since bought these for my spouse and mother-in-law a pari.

product_name: uvex skyper blue light blocking computer glasses with sct-orange lens (s1933x)
review_header: They were just what I was looking for, and needed!
review_text: These really work! My eyes were getting fatigued and tired when working for more than an hour on the computer. Also: the blue-spectrum light, when I did computer work at night, was stimulating my brain and causing insomnia. These do a great job of allowing me to work on the computer much longer, and at night, without negative repercussions. Due to problems (above-and-beyond computer use) with being sensitive to glare, and to night blindness, I also take MacuGuard supplements, and CAN-C eye drops. The combination of these three things have probably saved me from having severe eye problems, as I seemed to be heading that direction. Nice bonus: these tinted plastic-lens glasses are quite inexpensive.

review_text: These things suck. Seriously, what a joke. They're basically cheap orange safety glasses. I bought them because of the good review, and because they supposedly fit over your reading glasses, but they totally don't. Plus, even if they did, who wants to put on TWO pairs of glasses in order to read your ipad?? I ended up getting the Eyekepper Spring Hinge Two-Tone Color Computer Glasses in the strength I needed–they're reading glasses– and keep them on my nightstand. Perfect :)

product_name: uvex skyper blue light blocking computer glasses with sct-orange lens (s1933x)
review_text: My favorite product of 2017!!!! This has changed my life. And, given the horrible health impacts of no sleep, it may have just saved my life. How often can you say that about a product?! I've suffered with insomnia for years. I couldn't get to sleep easily and once I did, I couldn't stay asleep. I tried melatonin, sleeping pills, meditation, supplements, etc. Nothing worked. I had just about given up when I read an article about success in blocking blue light in the hours before bedtime. I took a chance and bought these which were featured in the article. And, WOW!!! It sounds crazy but these glasses have changed my life. The first night I wore them I slept like a baby! After 3 nights of great sleep, I tested the product by not wearing the glasses. And...back to the insomnia. :-( So, now I've set an alarm on my phone to remind me to put them on at 8:30p every night. By 10:30p, I'm falling asleep whether I want to or not! I've even woken up in the glasses because I fell asleep so soundly wearing them. Seriously, if you have insomnia, BUY THESE! They aren't cute and you may feel silly wearing them. But, when you feel your first good night's sleep after months or years of sleepless agony you'll be sold! I'm buying a second pair to keep in my travel kit.

product_name: uvex skyper blue light blocking computer glasses with sct-orange lens (s1933x)
review_header: They work, but wearing them isn't a great experience
review_text: They definitely make it much easier to fall asleep after watching TV or using the computer right before bed time. However, they're cumbersome, and while they do fit over my very small glasses, they keep sliding off the frame and need to be readjusted every time you move. So they definitely work, it just isn't particularly pleasant to use them. While they are good for blocking out the blue light from the TV so you can fall sleep more quickly, they aren't suitable for reading because they distort whatever is on the page or screen. The plastic "lens" is not optical quality, nor was it made to be. It was made to block blue light, which it does very well. However, if you're looking for something to block blue light when you're READING on your phone, iPad etc, these are most emphatically not a good choice. Buy a better quality pair of blue blocking glasses for that.

product_name: uvex skyper blue light blocking computer glasses with sct-orange lens (s1933x)
review_header: Sleeping well and waking happy! My chronic sleep problems have been resolved!
review_text: I can sleep at last! These orange Uvex Skyper glasses worn every evening - in combination with the Luminette Bright Light Theraply Glasses worn every morning - have totally transformed my life! Prior to buying these two items my sleep cycle had been appallingly since uni days. Years of working on a laptop all night in a brightly lit office had ruined my body's ability to regulate its sleep. I'd be bursting with energy at midnight, and then still powering away at dawn. It was easy to stay awake for 36 hours at time, but almost impossible to sleep. Mornings were just awful, and I'd feel lacklustre all day ... until about 7pm when my energy levels would begin to rise again. Over the years I had often tried to reform my sleep, but without any success; clearly, my brain was simply not producing melatonin. A few months ago I decided to start an experiment to see if cutting out blue light at night, and then adding bright blue light in the mornings, could overcome the chronic sleep problems. The science seemed valid, so I hoped it would work on me. I bought both the Uvex Skyper orange glasses (to block blue light in the evenings) and the Luminette glasses (to simulate bright daylight in the mornings) and used both diligently every day as part of a program to reform my sleep. Here's what I experienced. 1. Within a couple of weeks of wearing the Uvex Skyper glasses I started getting sleepy at around 11pm, like normal people do!! 2. After just a few mornings of wearing the Luminette glasses I began to enjoy waking up. I couldn't wait to pop on my "happy glasses" as they made me feel wonderful! Now, more than 2 months later, I wake every morning around 7am feeling bright and cheerful. 3. The quality of my sleep has been completely transformed. Only three months ago I would wake every half hour and then lie awake for another two or three hours; now I sleep soundly the whole night through! Based upon my experience, here are the key conclusions I'd to share with others. * If an inability to wind down or fall asleep is your main problem, then the orange Uvex Skyper glasses (around $9) should be your first purchase - because if you can kick-start your melatonin production at night, then you will sleep better and wake happier. * However, if you struggle to wake up and you feel sluggish for hours afterwards, then the Luminette glasses could be transformational for you (as they were for me). I used to hate mornings ... and now I love them! * You still need to be sufficiently self disciplined to use the specs diligently. E.g. if I forget to wear the orange glasses for a few nights, then my old habit of staying awake all night quickly returns. I'm writing this review jointly for the Uvex Skyper Blue Light Blocking Glasses (for evenings) and the Luminette 2 SAD Bright Light Therapy Glasses (for mornings) because I used both over the same time period and it isn't really possible to tell which of them has contributed most to resolving my sleep and wake problems.

product_name: uvex skyper blue light blocking computer glasses with sct-orange lens (s1933x)
review_header: Meh... You could do worse, You could do better,
review_text: These glasses do block blue light. The lenses are so dark, they block almost any color of light. I bought these at first for the price. After a few months, my children had gotten to them, cracked the lens (it is a single piece) right down the middle. Later they got to the ear pieces and that was the end of them. I felt that even on the brightest of screens these blocked too much to clearly see, and though the adjustable ear pieces were a nifty feature; all in all they felt more like outdoor construction glasses than anything else. Manufacturing: Cheap plastic. Seriously, they feel like a set of the cheapest Wal-Mart safety glasses. Feel: Uncomfortable to wear, the nose pieces are indelicate and will start to hurt after a while. To see out of them is difficult, and I felt like every time I put them away was the last time I would see them in one piece. Performance: They block light, are slightly oversized so you don't have to worry about fit, and the adjustable ear pieces with the wrap-around side blocking were useful features. However, I feel that being so fragile cancels the usefulness of these features out. Also, I found it difficult to see out of them, so much so that I found myself frequently removing them to get a better look at my screen. Conclusion: If you really have to be below $10 for blue blocking glasses, go ahead and purchase them. They block more blue light than any of the other three brands I have tried, which are Shileded, Beison and Gunnar Optiks. You won't get a headache from blue light when you are wearing these unless you are in the unlikely position of being more sensitive to light and prone to migraines as I am. Personally, I recommend you spend a few extra bucks and look for another brand. When the lens broke, I took a butane lighter and melted the crack together. It held for a few days, maybe a couple weeks, but eventually it gave out. Soon after, the earpiece went missing and now they are surely in the city dump.

product_name: uvex skyper blue light blocking computer glasses with sct-orange lens (s1933x)
review_header: Only good for reading or other black and white work
review_text: I bought these for a single purpose: to read on my smartphone or laptop at night. I have read that exposing yourself to blue light at night can keep you awake. This seems to be a scientifically based fact. While ideally I would completely stop looking at a screen at night, these are my go-to when I can't resist. I read that these shades block a very high percentage of blue light. Pros: they block a large amount of blue light. They are substantially less expensive than competing fashion frames that block a fraction of the blue light. Cons: Not office-attractive, but I only wear them at home. Only good for reading or other black and white work; designers up all night working who need full color and no distortion can't use any yellow lens, especially such intense ones as these. In sum, if you can't break your reading on-scren at night habit, these should help reduce the insomnia that can result.

product_name: uvex skyper blue light blocking computer glasses with sct-orange lens (s1933x)
review_header: but adjustable unless you have a tiny head like mine, in which case the ability to rotate ...
review_text: I work exclusively on computers for too many hours a day. After LASIK I decided to try out some glasses that block UV for work, since I no longer need my prescription lenses which had that protection. 1. They are chunky, but adjustable unless you have a tiny head like mine, in which case the ability to rotate them is more important than the ability to lengthen the arms. 2. The nose piece holds them well, but someone with a slight, never-broken nose might consider additional pads. 3. It blocks blue light. Our phone lights are blue plastic over white bulbs, and they look unlit with these on. 4. Greens look amazing, but if you need color differentiation visually, you'll either have to learn how the new colors look or go a less full route. 5. Normally looking at a computer screen leaves an after image when I close my eyes, or sometimes with them open. With these glasses there is either no after image or it fades in 1-2 seconds. 6. The design also blocks my desk fans from drying out my eyes, which is a nice bonus. Overall I have found this pair to block the most long blue light (visually, not as measured with a specific tool), and the reduction in after-images is a pleasant surprise. I don't need reading glasses yet, and I'm hoping to prolong indefinitely the time until I do.

review_header: It does change the colors pretty dramatically when you first put them on
review_text: I use these primarily to reduce blue light to aid my sleep quality. When I used the online blue light blocking test (where you compare two different color patterns) it seems to block out most of the blue light. So kudos from the blue light blocking perspective. It does change the colors pretty dramatically when you first put them on, but your eyes will adjust slightly and the picture (on your tv, etc) will look more acceptable over time (but of course, will not be nearly as good when watching without these!). The lenses are cheap plastic, but what do you expect for under $10? My primary issue is that these are huge and do not fit my face well. I have a low nose bridge and high cheekbones, so these sit on my cheekbones. As such these are not as comfortable as glasses that rest on my nose bridge, and I can see the bridge on the glasses when wearing them. Because of the poor fit, I tried another pair of "computer glasses" on Amazon. Although the other glasses had a slight yellow tint, when I tried the online test it appeared to not block much of the blue light so I returned them. If anyone has a recommendation on another brand of glasses that blocks most of the blue light please let me know! I may try the other UVEX glasses (S0360X) but my guess is these will not fit my face very well either.

My only caution is I wear wire-framed glasses and the curve on these can bend the frames a bit changing their focus. As a result I wear the Uvex glasses without my prescription glasses which means I miss most things printed on the t.v. screen, but the way this helps me at bedtime is worth it. I checked to see how much prescription blue light blockers would cost...OUCH! Ridiculously high.

review_text: I bought these for my husband to wear playing video games at night. I've got to give these glasses credit for being a great price and effectively blocking blue light. Though he didn't particularly like the color changes my husband thought they were fine for most video games, but he couldn't play one game that had a more muted color scheme. However, I've got to leave the review at one star because we simply can't use them. The way the lenses are molded as one clear piece creates distortions around the edges that were difficult for our brains to ignore. They made me motion sick just wearing them for a few minutes and gave my husband a headache about an hour in to wearing them.

I WOULD RECOMMEND Uvex Glasses I use this pretty much all the time, for computer use, for driving, and as protection when Mountain Biking (MTB). I think the MTB has abused them a bit as far as scratches, but it's been a good test. I'd say I have several hundred hours on these glasses with about 100 being riding trails. Visibility through the lenses has remained mostly unchanged & I expect them to last out the season and be replaced for next spring. I'd like a bit more durability with the lenses, but for $9, I think they are holding up well enough and as stated, they are comfy. I hope this review was helpful.

product_name: uvex skyper blue light blocking computer glasses with sct-orange lens (s1933x)
review_header: The Science May Be Undecided, But You Can't Deny the Results
review_text: The science may still be out on blue light blocking and it's impact on human sleeping patterns, but you can't deny that wearing the Uvex Skyper Blue Light Blockers at least makes you feel like you're accomplishing some good for your body. Put a pair on for 5 minutes and watch tv, stare at your phone, or work on your laptop, and if you slip them off you'll be amazed at how blinding that light suddenly feels. We just don't notice it because our eyes adjust. The Uvex glasses demonstrate just how bright it actually is. I purchased these because they appear to block more blue light than the other available options. While many competing products on here claim to block blue light, they ultimately have come up short in tests done by reviewers. These didn't. However, while the competitors may not effectively block blue light, at least they look somewhat normal. These look ridiculous. They are obviously designed as safety goggles for working with power tools and have been repurposed to satisfy the blue light crazed crowd. And that's fine with me, because they do the job well. But the idea of wearing these out of the house or at my job (which does not require any power tool beyond a computer) is laughable. My girlfriend still giggles every time I put them on, and, frankly, I don't blame her and thank her every time for not immediately leaving me. But, if you can get around all of that, for the price of these they really do seem to give your eyes a break. So put them on 30 minutes before you go to bed and let the scientists worry about whether it actually does anything to your melatonin production or not. It won't matter, because you'll definitely feel better.

And unlike another blue light blocking glasses that I ordered from another company, these do NOT have a strong chemical smell. No smell at all. Sure, I look kinda funny, and my family giggles and calls me Bono when I wear them, but it's worth not having migraines and eye pain anymore.

product_name: uvex skyper blue light blocking computer glasses with sct-orange lens (s1933x)
review_header: Disappointed ... or misunderstanding what these glasses & Blue Light really is
review_text: Perhaps I am misunderstanding Blue Light but after doing some research from several websites (i.e.:, (allaboutvision /cvs/blue-light) (reviewofoptometry /ce/the-lowdown-on-blue-light-good-vs-bad-and-its-connection-to-amd) (preventblindness.org/blue-light-and-your-eyes) I felt I had a pretty good idea of what to expect in a pair of Blue Light blocking glasses. Blue light is on the lower spectrum of visible light, not quite in the UV (UltraViolet) but close. Please correct me if I'm wrong; being visible light, true blue light blocking lenses would leave you seeing a black or dark grey where the blue light should be. This is a bit of a problem surfing the web as the links to other websites, normally blue, would be grey or black & be difficult to easily recognize without hovering the mouse over the link. From my research, these are not blue light blocking glasses. Every piece of blue on a computer screen, on an electronic led light, on a pair of bluejeans in the sunlight comes through these glasses as blue. The purpose for two stars is the disappointment in the advertising name of "Uvex Skyper Blue Light Blocking Computer glasses" when these are clearly not blue light blocking glasses. My intention was to purchase blue light blocking glasses. However, I do give them two stars because first, they are Uvex which means quality & secondly, they can still be used as a decent pair of safety glasses when trimming trees & shrubs, cutting lumber, etc.

review_header: Good decision! Uvex Skyper Blue Light Blocking is Helpful.
review_text: I purchased these because it seemed more effective to wear them for multiple uses, rather than pay $59 and up for a computer screen, TV screen, etc. I made the right decision to purchase wrap-around glasses. They aren't a perfect fit, as they tend to "push" away from the bridge of my nose, but it works well enough. I have noticed I fall asleep quickly when wearing these to watch TV late at night. My eyes feel more "rested" and less eyestrain when sitting in the dark and/or with minimal soft lighting. The ear pieces are adjustable, and if it weren't for the "push" effect annoyance, it would be a 5 star rating. Definitely would purchase again to aid in falling asleep when I get overstimulated by computer and/or television light. I need glasses to prevent some "blurriness" while I'm wearing these, and my thin wire frame prescription glasses fit well enough with these on, but usually I'm not wearing them because the point is to not end up staying awake hours past my bedtime. They work.

review_text: UGLY: They are U.G.L.Y. but I was willing to try them anyway based on their claim block nearly 100% of blue light. I really, really, hate the style though. I feel ridiculous with them on. TOO SMALL: When I opened the box, I thought I received kid's glasses because the sides were so short. They are adjustable, but I was afraid I was going to break them in the process. They don't fit over my prescription glasses, which isn't a big deal because I'm nearsighted. However, if you are far sighted this could be a problem for you. TOO DARK: Perhaps they block blue light but so do my eyelids. I feel I'm wearing sunglasses in the house. The color is too dark and very distracting. I can't imagine editing photos with these on or doing anything else where color is important. BOTTOM LINE: I wish I could return these but I've already thrown away the packing. I offered them to my husband but even he didn't want them and made a joke about me looking like a welder. :) I guess my kids will get them for play glasses.

Otherwise, it's pretty well made.

product_name: rolodex deep desk drawer organizer, metal mesh, black (22131)
review_header: Exceptional Product (regardless of the minor flaws)
review_text: The caddy is made out of metal that feels very sturdy to the touch. It designed provide a lot of space to place daily office supply in it and still have room for more. However, there are two flaws that I noticed and buyer should look out for: 1. The caddy's sheets of metal are not welded together, instead solder at both ends of the conjoining sheets. I have no fear of the caddy falling apart one day, but it's poor craftsmanship and attention to details that cause the product to lose value. 2. For detail-oriented individual, because the caddy's sheets of metal are solder, the walls are aligned 100% neatly next to each other. I have 2 of caddies (because one came without a tray and I had to get a free replacement) and one of them have a gap in the back of the caddy because the sheets of metal aren't aligned properly. Overall, I still recommend on buying this product. For the price-to-quality ratio, this product is best on the market as of right now. You honestly can't go wrong with this product. Buy it! I guarantee you would be happy with what you get.

review_header: Rolodex has made a relatively sturdy little caddy
review_text: I'm not sure if I should grade down Rolodex or Amazon as mine was missing the front drawer (quality control). As Amazon was the shipper, I think I can grade them separately. Rolodex has made a relatively sturdy little caddy. It doesn't look cheap by any means. In the end the missing drawer doesn't detract from what I personally need for the supply caddy. Else I would have requested a replacement. I've filled it with: sharpies, highlighters, signo pens and sakura micron pens (each with a rounded corner) and post-its in the remaining drawer and some stylus. It has eliminated the need in a junk drawer, so it's a step forward towards clearing that desk!

product_name: rolodex deep desk drawer organizer, metal mesh, black (22131)
review_text: I am a teacher, and my office supplies were all being held in the approximately 2 billion coffee mugs I've been given over the years. (I do drink a lot of coffee, but come on - I can only drink one cup at a time!) This organizer has the right number of "cups" for my scissors, pens, pencils, and markers. (The ones I need daily, anyway). I use the drawer for paperclips since I have a sticky note dispenser, but it will fit standard sticky notes. I like the shallow spots for a USB drive and other little doo-dads that I need (a stamp, correction fluid, etc.) My desk has never been more organized - and when I want to clean it, I no longer have to move 5 different coffee mugs!

review_text: This is a decent organizer for a desktop that doesn't have a lot of space to spare. I keep pens, pencils, scissors, and markers in the 4 tall sections; tape flags and paper clips in the shallow sections; Post-It notes in the pullout drawer. I like the fact that it's compact enough to easily pick up and move when necessary. There's no decorative side to this caddy, it's the type of no-frills organizer that looks at home in any generic office cubicle.

product_name: rolodex deep desk drawer organizer, metal mesh, black (22131)
review_header: Great organizer with a small footprint
review_text: I have had this style of Rolodex caddy at every one of my office desks and home office desk for the past 10 years. I love this organizer and my desk is just not complete without it.It has exactly the right amount of cubbies and pen holders that I need. The drawer is a bonus where I can tuck away other small things like memory sticks or white out. The caddy's small footprint means it doesn't take up a lot of space on my desk, yet it's so well thought out in how it breaks up and uses space that it holds many more bits and bobs than you'd think.

product_name: rolodex deep desk drawer organizer, metal mesh, black (22131)
review_text: I have a large desk for my computer and monitor but evidently it is not large enough! I have so much stuff on my desk that I can never find anything. I also have a fan that sits on the desk, box of tissue, small wooden organizer that has drawers and shelves, and numerous papers. I can never find a pencil when I need one to jot something down, and forget about paperclips, etc. This caddy is perfect for my needs. I have numerous pencils standing up (and not falling over), magic markers, highlight pens, nail clippers, Emory boards, and paperclips all that fit in this caddy nicely. Now I am not hunting for anything any more--it is all right in front of me. I would buy this caddy again.

product_name: dymo labelmanager 280 rechargeable hand-held label maker (1815990)
review_header: Amazon gave me a great price!
review_text: Easy to use and does the job, but has two issues. 1. the power button does not always work the first time you push it. 2. I could not see a way to adjust the marginal space at the start and end of printing. I don't want white tails off my labels, so I just cut them off. This means I am wasting a lot of label tape that I don't need to - and other models I have used at work allow you to reduce the margin space. I think this machine was designed to have too much margin in order to run out of label tape faster and have to buy more sooner. Overall, I bought this on amazon for under $20 - what great price compared to what I saw others pay! So for that reason alone, I am ok having to cut some tails off.

product_name: dymo labelmanager 280 rechargeable hand-held label maker (1815990)
review_header: Battery issues. Easily overcome if you're a tinkerer.
review_text: Overall, I'm very happy with it. The quality of the labels is good, it doesn't waste a TON of material, (though it could be less) and the app interface is good. The reason I'm deducting stars is that I had to repair the battery, which seems like a common issue with this product, based on the other reviews that I've read. I used it for about a year, then packed it away for another year. When I took it out of storage, I got a low battery error when trying print, even after letting the battery charge for hours. I removed the battery pack from the printer, and split the case halves apart with a utility knife. There are two 14430 (4/5AA) LiIon cells inside. With a hobby battery charger, I attempted to discharge and charge the battery cells. They were completely dead. I purchased replacement cells here on Amazon, (http://a.co/9VkSnFR) and soldered everything back together. The printer's working great again, but unless you're good at soldering and enjoy tinkering, be aware that you'll probably have to buy a new battery pack, or repair the pack at some point. This product only has two stars on Dymo's website, and almost all of the negative reviews have to do with the battery.

review_header: it does the job great! a little clunky, but good quality printing and labels. can't beat the price. i got it for 13.99
review_text: i use this for labeling network cables, switch ports, patch panels, and many other network-related items. it is small, compact, and easy to carry or store. i have only used it with basic functions. font-size can be changed, bolded, underlined, or italicized. characters can me changed to print vertically or horizontally (a nice feature). i am not entirely happy with the keyboard functionality. there is no clear, so you have to backspace, one at a time (pressing and holding is also slow going). it also takes 6 AAA batteries. you could buy an ac adapter, but that obviously reduces mobility. all in all, it does the job great! a little clunky, but good quality printing and labels. can't beat the price. i got it for 13.99!!!

review_text: The directions are pretty scarce. If you tinker around with it you can figure it out. I had the hardest time trying to change the language to English. I can't find a clear button to erase the screen so I have to delete the previous word after every entry. There is no backspace so that I can go back without erasing and add a letter or correct a typo. The cutter seems to be razor sharp and cuts effortlessly. Cannot adjust the amount of unused label before and after a word. Great print with enough options on handheld. I did not hook up to computer. Be aware and check the size/font when you turn unit off and on it seems to reset itself to default. Overall the quality is superb. Nice soft touch keys. It has it's pros and cons but I would definitely buy again.

product_name: dymo labelmanager 280 rechargeable hand-held label maker (1815990)
review_text: Look close when you read the reviews here because it appears many different products are being covered. My review is for the DYMO LabelManager 160 Handheld Label Maker. I was looking for a basic label maker for an electronics project I’m working on mainly, and anything around the house where a label would be helpful. I paid a little more than I wanted to, but I figured I would buy it, use it for my project, then sell it. It’s kind of like renting a brand new device and then getting most of my money back. Anyway, it arrived quickly, I was pleased with the size and layout of the keyboard, and it was easy to begin using it. After inserting the blank roll of label tape I tried my first test label. The first label did not come out because it snagged inside label pathway. I saw it as my mistake for not threading the cartridge correctly on my first attempt. It really wasn’t complicated at all, just one of those little things that happened because I had never used it before. Opening the back again I was able to quickly fix the threading problem and start creating labels. I was now able to quickly type and print labels with ease, and no more jams. I like that the current label does not automatically get deleted after it prints. Sometimes I needed the same label like “On - Off” for several switches on my project board. Once the first label printed I pressed the cut icon then immediately pressed print again without having to retype. I’ve found in life you can pick apart pretty much anything, but I don’t feel this product is one of them. For the price I paid and the capability that it gives me I’m pleased with the LM 160.

product_name: dymo labelmanager 280 rechargeable hand-held label maker (1815990)
review_text: I'd been looking for a label maker to better organize my nail polish swatch sticks as well as other craft supplies. After looking at some more expensive options I settled for this and for the price point I'm very impressed (and it's actually gone down a couple of dollars since my purchase). It prints cleanly and the device is pretty intuitive, though if you're struggling you can find the manual at the Dymo website. Batteries are not included nor is the compatible ac adapter. It does however come with a sample roll of tape. All the labels in the photo, give or take a few practice labels and typos, were printed using the sample roll!

product_name: dymo labelmanager 280 rechargeable hand-held label maker (1815990)
review_text: Great for labeling storage items!

product_name: dymo labelmanager 280 rechargeable hand-held label maker (1815990)
review_text: I have the Brother label printer at my workplace, and that unit is almost perfect except that it wastes a lot of tape with each printout. I bought this Dymo economy unit for occasional home use. It’s great that it doesn’t waste much tape. My only disappointment is that it comes with a caps lock button but no shift button. I consider myself part of the tech-savvy generation, who by default types quickly and professionally, and no Shift button is just an annoying handicap that clumsifies and slows down my label making experience. I guess that wouldn’t matter if you’re one of those people who always type in ALL-CAPS. Also, it seems about 10% of buyers (myself included) receive defective units where the drive motor won’t turn the tape spool. Before you return it, there’s a trick. If the unit sits on the shelf for years before getting sold, the motor bearings apparently seize up. All you have to do is remove the tape cartridge and unseize the motor by turning it a bit with your fingers. You will hear a mild pop sound and feel when the motor is unseized. My printer has been fine ever since.

product_name: dymo labelmanager 280 rechargeable hand-held label maker (1815990)
review_text: Received unit, went and bought 6, AAA batteries, fired it up, and only to find out Amazon sent me a broken unit. Every time I would try to print, no tape would come out, and it made an ugly noise as if components were grinding. I triple checked everything, referred to the owners manual, but this was not a use error. Upon taking a closer look at the packaging and the unit itself, it had scratch marks all over the front and back. This leaves me to think that the "new" one I paid for was actually an open box return, by someone who probably had the same issue with it and didn't bother to tell amazon or DYMO the truth. Amazon cant return the extra tape I bought to which is classic.

product_name: dymo labelmanager 280 rechargeable hand-held label maker (1815990)
review_header: Works Fine Until It Goes Digital
review_text: Used very little--labels for home files and toiletries when traveling. About the fifth use, it started giving a "label jammed" error message, although the label paper was not jammed. Went online and learned that this is an electronic error and tried the suggested fix, which did not work. Contacted the company, which sent me essentially the same suggested fix, which did not work again. When I emailed back that my machine was still not working, did not hear from DYMO again. So customer service is nil, and product is unreliable.

product_name: dymo labelmanager 280 rechargeable hand-held label maker (1815990)
review_text: I bought this label maker so I could label the kids' backpack cubbies at the daycare I work at, to keep all their stuff in one place and to avoid things going missing like what's been happening lately. It's awesome. It's very easy to use with a simple design, not bulky or heavy at all. It fits perfectly in my hand and I can type out things so easily. The adhesive feature is really nice and it doesn't stick to wood to the point where it won't come off; I can pull the labels off if need be, but they don't come off by themselves. I've only ever used this brand of label makers. My mom has an older model (about a decade old) and it still works. No longer missing anything, as these labels really helped and I don't have any problems with this model. Highly recommend, especially for work use.

product_name: dymo labelmanager 280 rechargeable hand-held label maker (1815990)
review_header: I contacted DYMO support via live chat and had a broken English conversation with a tech how was useless at trouble shooting
review_text: This label printer is not ready for prime time. I am using a Mac running High Sierra, the first step in setting this up is to hook the printer up via USB, open the app that is stored in the printer and configure it for wireless. I was able to open the app but never could get it to print a label connected locally. I was able to configure the wireless setting and get the device on my network but then after downloading the desktop application I could never print to the printer via wireless. I would get the error message "printer not responding". I contacted DYMO support via live chat and had a broken English conversation with a tech how was useless at trouble shooting. She was asking questions like "is the power turned on?". Duh. Anyway, I was able to print one label with the printer hooked up locally after downloading the latest rev of their desktop app but never via wireless and I spent way to much time trying. I have had good luck with Brother printers in the past and I see they make a wireless label printer so I will give it a try. The reason I didn't buy the brother in the first place was that it was twice the cost of the DYMO. But I got zero value for my money with the DYMO anyway.

product_name: dymo labelmanager 280 rechargeable hand-held label maker (1815990)
review_text: This little device has been so frustrating and time consuming. I have downloaded software online, I have called our IT department, I have called customer service and was told they were in a meeting, called back and currently sitting waiting for 15+ min and counting. I've even watched youtube videos to see if it was something I was missing, and changed cables in case of a bad wire. NOTHING has WORKED. I think their customer service plays relaxing spa music so you wont go bananas on them. This has been the WORST product I have purchased online. If I had my timeframe to return I would have done it along time ago. It is my fault that I waited too long to return. Just so all reviewers know... I have a MacBook Air, I have the latest software, and guess what... the concept of "PLUG and PLAY" is a darn joke. This has been more like PLUG and THROW AWAY!!!!!!! **** Update: I have contacted DYMO customer service again and have found out the battery was not in the battery compartment, which means it will not work. I assumed with the light turning on it was getting power. Unfortunately this was a packaging error and incomplete project causing me so much wasted time. The man helping me did figure out the problem and although at times condescending in tone was overall helpful, which was obviously the goal. He also is sending me a battery at no charge as it is in warranty. This was nice of him. Stay tuned for change in star rating or not.

product_name: dymo labelmanager 280 rechargeable hand-held label maker (1815990)
review_text: Well, now my whole world is labeled. The DYMO labeler makes it way too easy to label and organize. Buy it and you might get carried away. The reviewer who showed a photo of a cat with the label "cat" did not hyperbolize. I spent a day organizing and labeling bins in our storage room and now it's as orderly as a well-run library. And then I labeled the garage parts/hardware drawer organizer. And then the repurposed plastic spray bottles full of distilled water, bleach mixes, cleaners, etc. Limitless opportunities!! A little tape seems to go a long way, but I bought a 25 foot refill just in case. It takes a little playing around to decide which font sizes work well for what purposes, but it's an easy device to figure out. Two special requests for their product developers: Please put common symbols right on the keyboard so we don't have to scroll through a menu to find dashes, slashes and ampersands. And please provide a single button that wipes out all the text when we create a new label. It's a pain to only have the backspace button to do the job (prospective purchaser please note that when you turn the label maker on, it will come up with the text of the last label you made, not a new clean slate). Otherwise, a very fun and potentially obsessive toy for home and office organization.

product_name: dymo labelmanager 280 rechargeable hand-held label maker (1815990)
review_header: Makes good labels but room for improvement.
review_text: I liked that it prints clear. I used it to label keys on an electric piano. I used 1/2" black tape and placed the labels above the keys on the keyboard. It was hard getting the spacing because the display on the label maker does not show you the actual size of the characters. When printing two lines of text if you line up the top and bottom rows on the display then they do not print out lined up on the label. When printing two line labels the font would change to a smaller font. The largest font size that I could use for a two line label was 12 point. 2 lines of 12 point only uses about 2/3 of the width of the label. I have been looking for some 1/4" black label tape but cannot find it anywhere. It has a proprietary battery which according to another review costs as much as the label maker. It does not work on the charger without a battery. It did not come with a driver for Linux. Did get the job done eventually but I wasted a lot of label in the process.

product_name: dymo labelmanager 280 rechargeable hand-held label maker (1815990)
review_header: Works with off-brand label tape - rechargeable battery works great!
review_text: My issue with label makers in general before this were: 1) they eat batteries or are always dead when you need them 2) the label tape is so expensive I can't help myself from calculating the cost per label... This is the first rechargeable label maker I've owned. Instead of using AA batteries that are dead every time you need it, it has built in battery that lasts a good long time (months depending on use). Another reason I picked it up specifically was so I can get generic branded labels for much cheaper than typical label makers sell their tape for. I really like the fact it has built in memory. I have some labels (please return this book to... for example) which makes it easy to reprint more labels each month (or week).

product_name: dymo labelmanager 280 rechargeable hand-held label maker (1815990)
review_header: Why so many positive reviews, I don't get it at all.
review_text: I bought this thing because of all the positive reviews. I don't know what all those positive reviews are for unless none of the users have ever used a Brother label maker before. 4 lines of text on 3/4" tape was blotchy, faint, and hard to read. Customer service was horrible, supposed to open online chat at 9 am (EST), didn't open till after 10 am, but no one was actually taking texts. Save yourself some heartache and get a cheaper PT-D600 by Brother. By the time customer service was answering chat, I had processed the return, made it to Office Depot, and back to the office. They said the tape may have been old...the product was brand new in the box from Amazon...I have TZ tape that is over 10 years old and it still prints just fine. What is Brother doing to their tapes to make them last so long that Dymo is not doing? Also, the Dymo 420P does not allow for text going across from left to right in Portrait View...only down the label. I guess Dymo also does not care about customer service or any sort of feedback as they just ended the chat when I tried to give them some usable feedback about their product. Oh, and the 420P won't work without a battery in place. Good luck to Dymo owners.

I tried to set both machines to the most narrow font ( dymo didn't have fonts) at different font sizes smallest and largest. I've had them both for a few months and I dont know where the DYMO instructions are, so if there are other font types, I couldn't find them easily. review_header: The device is pretty simple to hook up and use
review_text: The device is pretty simple to hook up and use. Under Windows 10, the application does NOT automatically pop up; I had to go looking for it and create a desktop shortcut. No big deal. The labels print cleanly and sharply, even down to very small font sizes. The only thing keeping me from giving it 5 stars is that the label tape is not all that "sticky" and peels off a bit too easily on several of the items I've tried to label. product_name: dymo labelmanager 280 rechargeable hand-held label maker (1815990)
review_text: I would like to preface this review by saying I love Amazon. You cant beat their prices and their customer service. My usual means of buying stuff here is to read the reviews and see what people say. I also consider the number of 4/5 star reviews, the more of them often indicating a product excels in quality and performance. With that in mind I bought this DYMO label maker. I used it once and it worked fine. I removed the batteries because I didnt know when it would be used again. To my surprise it was needed a few days later so in goes the batteries and I tried to print.It sputtered and gave an error message " TAPE JAM " . I opened the back and removed tape to examine it and the feed area. All looked good so I fed a little of tape out and replaced properly and tried agin. I got the same thing.I then opened a new tape and repeated the whole procedure to no avail. Then I began to watch youtube videos to see what could be wrong. I found one where a guy described my same issues and gave a fix of turning the drive shaft clock wise five times with your hand and activating the on switch. I tired that, replaced the tape , fed it through with extra tape on the end and still the same error message. At that point I sent it back and bought a Brother. Maybe I got a dud? Maybe I got the one out of many that was doomed to fail but I gave up on it. Thanks to Amazon for taking it back and even having U.P.S. pick it up.

product_name: dymo labelmanager 280 rechargeable hand-held label maker (1815990)
review_header: Plays well with Windows, but not Mac... 4 stars, 5 if played nice with Mac.
review_text: UPDATE: Lowering to 4 stars due to poor Mac support. This label maker sucks on Mac, the light software would not work at all on Mac. The downloaded software had to be 8.5.2, and it still stopped working, and full re-install didn't get it going. Below are instructions to help delete the proper files, but I quit on the 3rd time it quit... I'm not re-installing software everytime I use the label maker. Possible driver conflicts. They got four hours of my life, and I'm not going to use terminal to troubleshoot their driver or conflict issues or whatever is happening - ( bad Mac support Dymo). I run a late 2012 MacMini on High Sierra, and it's up to date as of 2/3/18, upgraded, and it's a very dependable Mac. (Possibly interfering with my network HP printer drivers?) ANYWAY: On windows 10, the light software could work, but I still had to download v8.7 from Dymo to change fonts. So far it plays nice with Windows, and I will update if that is not the case in the near future... MAC NOTES: Enter the following review and use it if you like to play with Mac and figure stuff out, but I decided to grab my dusty miniPC from storage and print my labels from Windows. GOOD LUCK.... This is a simple black and white printer for making labels. The ease of use is very good. With my Mac, I had to download the software from the internet to make it work properly. As such, it was slightly more work than promised. After inserting the included battery, and roll of tape, plugging in the USB and power adapter, the unit powered on and the software came up - see your instructions. On a Mac, the included software popped up but wouldn't let me click inside the label to edit my label, make a new label, or print. The upper right icon in the light software CAN be clicked to download newest version software... then on Mac, you drag and drop to Applications and wait for it to install - took 5-10 minutes for mine... then, you can change fonts and sizes and print labels. Finally, after going through these software issues, I do have a small profile label maker at a price I can handle. Kudos to Dymo for reaching out to the non-OCD people who don't want to spend too much on labels we don't make very often. Check the different options for label tape on Amazon or the Dymo website. You can find more options there to go with your purchase. Reasonable and effective solution to orgazining my electronics so I know where all my cables and things are.

review_header: Pleasantly Surprised By The Quality, Excellent Overall Quality... Just Buy It!
review_text: I got tired of using small address labels, handwritten, to keep my boxes and folders straight. I have to admit I did not have overly high hopes for this DYMO 160 based on the low price but I took the plunge anyway. I wanted the labels for polypropylene boxes, these from Sterlite: Sterilite 19638606 Large Clip Box, Clear with Blue Aquarium Latches, 6-Pack I am really happy to say the DYMO labels stick very nicely to the boxes! As far as the machine itself, simple, simple, simple to use and produces really nice labels. I didn't even know when I bought it that it could print 2 lines as well as a single (larger font) line. For $20... just buy it! In addition to a very smooth operation, the unit itself has a very solid feel to it. It comes with a modest 10' roll of tape, I've been able to print quite a few labels with this and I just ordered 2 of the 23' replacement cartridges. Overall really nice job DYMO, this is a heck of a good value!

product_name: dymo labelmanager 280 rechargeable hand-held label maker (1815990)
review_text: This is a great labeler at a great price. It truly is plug and play. The device installed automatically on my Windows 10 laptop. The lite version of the software runs directly from a drive partition located on the labeler. The full version of Dymo’s labeling software is available for download from The Dymo website. The use of the fonts on my computer is a real plus and being able to put more than 2 lines of text on a label is awesome. Adding a barcode automatically via the software is a real plus as well as capturing a part of the screen or a graphic file. Of course there are severe size limitations. If you don’t need a portable labeler and want versatility then this is for you.

The price is great and now I can put labels on various things in the shop. My only real complaint is that, on some surfaces (some plastics from what I've found), the adhesive back doesn't want to stick. Would be nice if that were a bit more...sticky? On the flip side, it's real easy to take off if you need to relabel something so there is that aspect. Overall, a great value.

product_name: dymo labelmanager 280 rechargeable hand-held label maker (1815990)
review_text: The label maker works as described and is very easy to install, also to download the software and create labels. It just plugs into a powered USB port on a computer, which recharges its battery. It does, as most label makers, cut off quite a bit of unprinted tape, but no more than any other label maker I've used. Since it has to be plugged into a computer, it's not as portable as the handheld Dymo that I had previously, but once the software is opened on my computer, it's much easier to make labels using my keyboard than the keyboard on a handheld label maker. The software lets you insert text, an automatic updating counter, a few simple shapes and lines, barcodes, auto-updating date and time, circular text, and addresses from an address book (mine came with a dozen addresses -- maybe someone pre-owned my label maker??). You can also import your own graphics. Great choices -- the only problem is, I'm using the supplied 1/2 tape, so there's not much room. I uploaded and added a photo go a label, but it's very tiny. Still, useful software, mostly for borders and a good selection of fonts, sizes, and colors. Much more versatile than the hand-held label maker I'd been using. I experimented for quite a while and haven't yet used up the sample tape supplied, but I did purchase three extra, full-sized rolls -- black on white, black on clear, and white on clear. I thought of purchasing a wireless version, but there were too many problems cited in reviews. Happy, for now, with this purchase.

product_name: dymo labelmanager 280 rechargeable hand-held label maker (1815990)
review_text: I thought this label maker was great at first. It's easy to create labels and they look nice. However, 2 months later all the labels have fallen off. The label tape is too thick and not sticky enough. I would return it all if I could.

product_name: dymo labelmanager 280 rechargeable hand-held label maker (1815990)
review_header: At first this kept saying Label Jam and wouldn't print ...
review_text: At first this kept saying Label Jam and wouldn't print at all. Brand new everything. After some searches I learned that you can fix this by removing the print cassette and manually turn the black spool thing clockwise. It will be very stiff and require force. Once you've done this a few times, reincert the print cassette and it should work.

product_name: dymo labelmanager 280 rechargeable hand-held label maker (1815990)
review_header: Beats Brother in every way...except only ONE font!
review_text: A label maker is an organizational MUST HAVE and this brand/model is a great option for those new to labeling (oh the joy! I'm so excited for you!)! I already own a Brother brand labeler myself and bought this for a friend for Christmas. I was anxious to compare the two. Here's the skinny on this Dymo: - Cheaper than brother (both the unit itself and the tape cartridges) - Intuitive and easy to use - Love the QWERTY keyboard - Love that it has different outline, underline, text size and style options - LOVE that it doesn't waste NEARLY as much tape on the sides as my Brother model does (which can't be changed in settings). This is one of the major selling points for Dymo over Brother in my opinion. The tape cartirdges aren't cheap and when so much tape is wasted on either side of your text (which I usually just end up clipping off anyway) that really adds up! Hooray Dymo! The only thing that is lame about this particular model is that it only comes with ONE FONT. While the description is technically correct, I will say that it mislead me to believe that I would be getting multiple fonts when it told me there were 6 font styles. I have no idea what they think the difference is between 'font style' and 'text style' but to me a 'font style' is simply a different font and a 'text style' is referring to bold, italics etc. This feels very misleading and confusing and I am disappointed that there is only one font. Even 2 or 3 to choose from would be nice. That's where my Brother wins out. But that's the only area. Everything else about this labeler is fantastic! If I had to buy a new one for myself, I'd buy this one over the Brother in a heart beat. Hope this helps!

product_name: dymo labelmanager 280 rechargeable hand-held label maker (1815990)
review_header: everything seemed fine until I pressed print at which point it stalled ...
review_text: The overall quality is consistent with the low price. When inserting batteries (6 AAA!) make sure they're all firmly in place - when I first installed mine, everything seemed fine until I pressed print at which point it stalled and gave a lower battery warning. Re-seating the batteries resolved this. Additionally, I've had the tape get stuck a couple times which is annoying and very wasteful. The keyboard is pretty good - typing is fine, though hunting for any additional characters is an exercise in patience. Also would have been nice if there was an easy way to have different font sizes for each of the rows of text. Overall does what I need and nothing more - purchased only because of the price.
